     … C M B …

3.  “C sits 4 places to the left of L.”  
    Therefore if C is in seat k, L must be in seat k + 4.  
    Trying every possible position of the triple C M B (while keeping the table 10 seats
    long and leaving room for L four seats to the right) leaves only two feasible
    locations:

           Case A Seats 1–3 :  C1  M2  B3 ⇒ L is in seat 5
           Case B Seats 2–4 :  C2  M3  B4 ⇒ L is in seat 6

    Any further to the right would force L into seat 8, 9 or 10, but those three seats have
    to be occupied by S, E and Z (see step 5), so no other placement works.

4.  “L sits next to O” and “O does not sit next to the owner of the bank.”  
    •  In Case A (L in seat 5) O can only go into seat 6 (seat 4 would put O next to B in
       seat 3, which is forbidden).  
    •  In Case B (L in seat 6) O can only go into seat 7 (seat 5 would again put O next to
       the owner in seat 4).

5.  “S, E and Z … sit on the far right of the bank.”  
    Interpret “far right” naturally as the three right-hand-most seats, i.e. seats 8, 9 and 10.
    (Their internal order is irrelevant – only the fact that the three seats are reserved
    for them matters.)

    With seats 8–10 fixed for {S,E,Z}, Case B is still possible (O went to seat 7, the last
    free place before the block 8–10).  
    Case A is also still possible.

6.  All that remains to be placed are F and T, and we are told exactly that:
    “The two people left are F and T. T hates the owner of the bank.”  
    We simply keep T from sitting next to B.

    •  Case A (so far 1 C 2 M 3 B 5 L 6 O 8–10 S/E/Z)  
       The empty seats are 4 and 7.  
       Seat 4 is next to the owner, seat 7 is not.  
       Hence 4 F, 7 T.

    •  Case B (so far 2 C 3 M 4 B 6 L 7 O 8–10 S/E/Z)  
       The empty seats are 1 and 5.  
       Seat 5 is next to the owner, seat 1 is not.  
       Hence 1 T, 5 F.

    Both partial diagrams satisfy every given condition; the only difference is which of
    the two admissible ways we chose to seat the initial block C M B.

Because the exact order of S, E and Z on the far-right three chairs is not stated (and does
not affect any other rule) we may list them in any order; likewise either of the two
complete layouts works.  A perfectly valid seating, reading from left to right, is therefore

Seat 1   C  
Seat 2   M  
Seat 3   B (the Owner)  
Seat 4   F  
Seat 5   L  
Seat 6   O  
Seat 7   T  
Seat 8   S  
Seat 9   E  
Seat 10  Z  

Thus the bankers, left-to-right, can be read as

Final answer: C, M, B, F, L, O, T, S, E, Z

Question:
Question: You and your spouse invite four other couples to a party. During the course of the conversation, it is discovered that, prior to the party, each person except you was acquainted with a different number of the people present. Assuming the acquaintance relationship is symmetric (i.e., if you are acquainted with someone, that person is also acquainted with you), then how many people did your spouse know prior to the party? How many people did you know?
 Hint: nan
Human Solution:
Start with the assumption that everybody knows their own spouses -- which means that everybody there knew at least one person. Discounting yourself, everyone knows a different number of people, which means that (again, discounting yourself) one person knows one, one person knows two, one person knows three, etc., up to one person who knows nine people (everybody else). Number the people (besides yourself) according to how many people they know, so that person 1 is the one who knows one person, person 2 is the one who knows two people, etc.
Now pair up people with their spouses. If person 9 knows everybody else, s/he must be the only person who knows person 1, because person 1 only knows one person. So they must be married. Person 8 knows everybody except for person 1. Person 2 therefore knows person 8 and person 9. Person 9 is married to person 1, so person 2's spouse must be person 8. Person 7 knows everybody except for persons 1 and 2. Person 3 therefore knows persons 7, 8, and 9. Persons 8 and 9 are married to persons 2 and 1 respectively, so person 3's spouse must be person 7. Person 6 knows everybody except for persons 1, 2, and 3. Person 4 therefore knows persons 6, 7, 8, and 9. The only one of those not yet paired up is person 6, so person 4 and person 6 must be married.
This leaves person 5, who knows everyone except persons 1, 2, 3, and 4. These five people, therefore, must be persons 6, 7, 8, 9, and you. Since you are the only one of these five not yet paired up, person 5 must be your spouse. So your spouse knew five people prior to the party.
The above also determines that the people who know you are persons 5, 6, 7, 8, and 9. So you knew five people prior to the party also.
Response:
Let the ten people at the party be the vertices of a graph.
For every two people who were acquainted before the party we draw an (undirected) edge, so that the degree of a vertex is the number of people that person already knew.

Facts that are given or obvious  

•  There are 5 married couples; call the partners of a couple “spouses”.  
•  Acquaintance is symmetric, so degrees really count the number of edges incident with a vertex.  
•  Every person knows his or her own spouse, so everyone has degree ≥1.  
•  Of the other nine people (everybody except you) the degrees are all different.

Step 1 – which nine different numbers can occur?  
Since every degree is at least 1, the only possible distinct degrees for the nine other people are  

1,2,3,4,5,6,7,8,9 .

Step 2 – the extreme degrees must be spouses  

Let A be the person whose degree is 9 and B the person whose degree is 1.  
Because B knows exactly one person, that person has to be B’s spouse.  
If A were not B’s spouse, then B would not know A; by symmetry A would not know B either, contradicting the fact that A knows everybody.  
Hence the degree-9 person and the degree-1 person are a married couple.

Step 3 – remove that couple and repeat  

Delete A and B from consideration.  
Among the eight remaining people the smallest degree is 2 and the largest is 8; the same argument shows that the degree-8 person and degree-2 person must be spouses.  
Delete them and continue:

degree-7 is married to degree-3,  
degree-6 is married to degree-4.

After removing these four couples, only one couple is left, namely you and your spouse, and the only unused degree is 5.  Therefore both you and your spouse must have degree 5.

Conclusion  

Your spouse knew 5 of the 9 other people, and (perhaps to your own surprise) you also knew exactly 5 of them.

Final answer: Your spouse knew 5 people, and you knew 5 people.

Question:
Question: Nick has always wanted one, so he goes out and buys a brand new one for £5000.  Unfortunately the next day he breaks it, so he goes out again and gets another brand new one. This time however, it only costs him £25. The next day someone offers to buy it off of him for £6000.
What is it ?
 Hint: nan
Human Solution: A personalised number plate.

Question:
Question: Four friends named Jane, June, Jean and Jenny discovered that, if a different non-zero integer was assigned to each letter of their names and added together, it produced their ages.
June is 17, Jenny is two years older, while Jane and Jean are both sweet 16.  All the girls agree that June is in her prime.  Can you find the numbers the girls assigned to each letter of their names?
(There are two possible answers.)
 Hint: prime...
Hint: prime...
Human Solution:
J=2; U=7; N=5; E=3; A=6; Y=4
or
J=3; U=7; N=5; E=2; A=6; Y=4
The little clue 'June is in her prime' should have helped, as it suggests that all the numbers in her name are prime numbers.  As the total is 17 all the numbers must be less than 10, so:
J=2; U=7; N=5; E=3  (or J=3; U=7; N=5; E=2)
Setting these numbers in the word Jane or Jean we can conclude that
16=2+A+5+3, so A=6.
Putting these numbers in the word Jenny in the same way we find Y=4.
Response:
Step-1.  Name every different letter with a variable  

 J, A, N, E, U, Y are the six different letters that occur in the four names.

Step-2.  Translate the four statements “the sum of the letters equals the age”

 June  J + U + N + E = 17                (1)  
 Jenny J + E + N + N + Y = 19 → J + E + 2N + Y = 19 (2)  
 Jane  J + A + N + E = 16                (3)  
 Jean  J + E + A + N = 16 – same as (3)

Step-3.  Eliminate to obtain simple relations

 Subtract (1) from (3): A − U = −1 ⇒ A = U − 1       (4)  
 Subtract (1) from (2): N + Y − U = 2 ⇒ Y = U + 2 − N  (5)

Step-4.  Use the hint “prime”

 June is 17 (a prime), and the hint suggests taking the letters of JUNE to be primes.  
 We need four different primes whose sum is 17.  
 The only possible set is 2, 3, 5, 7 because  

  2 + 3 + 5 + 7 = 17

 Consequently       {J, U, N, E} is a permutation of {2, 3, 5, 7}.

Step-5.  Try every choice for U and enforce the relations (4) and (5)

 • U = 2 ⇒ A = 1, N + Y = 4  
  N must be 3, 5 or 7 – none of them gives a new, positive Y different from every other letter.  
  (If N = 5 we get Y = −1, which is allowed but gives a negative value.  
   We are after positive ages, so discard this case.)

 • U = 3 ⇒ A = 2, N + Y = 5  
  The only way N + Y = 5 with unused numbers is N = 7, Y = −2 (negative again).  
  Discard.

 • U = 5 ⇒ A = 4, N + Y = 7  
  N = 2 gives Y = 5 (clashes with U); N = 3 gives Y = 4 (clashes with A);  
  N = 7 gives Y = 0 (zero not allowed).  Discard.

 • U = 7 ⇒ A = 6, N + Y = 9  
  N can be 5 (then Y = 4) – all values are positive and different.  
  This choice works.

So we must have

 U = 7, A = 6, N = 5, Y = 4.

Step-6.  Determine J and E

With U = 7 and N = 5 equation (1) gives

 J + E = 17 − (U + N) = 17 − 12 = 5.

The only two unused numbers left are 2 and 3, and indeed 2 + 3 = 5.  
Either letter may take either value:

 Case I J = 2, E = 3  
 Case II J = 3, E = 2

Both satisfy every requirement, and all six letters have different non-zero integers.

Hence the two possible complete assignments are

 Case I J = 2, A = 6, N = 5, E = 3, U = 7, Y = 4  
 Case II J = 3, A = 6, N = 5, E = 2, U = 7, Y = 4

They give the correct ages:

 June 7 + 2 + 5 + 3 = 17, or 7 + 3 + 5 + 2 = 17  
 Jenny 2 + 3 + 5 + 5 + 4 = 19, or 3 + 2 + 5 + 5 + 4 = 19  
 Jane/Jean 2 + 6 + 5 + 3 = 16, or 3 + 6 + 5 + 2 = 16.

Therefore there are exactly two (mirror-image) solutions.

Final answer: The letters can be valued either  
 J = 2, A = 6, N = 5, E = 3, U = 7, Y = 4 or J = 3, A = 6, N = 5, E = 2, U = 7, Y = 4.

Question:
Question: Some office workers were holding a daily pool on the number of doughnuts their boss would eat each weekday morning during March. Each person set aside funds in their desk with which to bet. Each day from Monday, March 3rd, they all bet a dollar - Kevin bet on 2, Kate on 3 and Kathy on 3.5 doughnuts. Kathy won twice as many times as Kevin, who was right once more than Kate; sometimes there was no winner. By April, they all had $20 in their desks. How much was the most anyone could have had in their desk at the beginning of March?
 Hint: The pot does not accumulate if there is no winner - each person gets his "stake" back.
Hint: The pot does not accumulate if there is no winner - each person gets his "stake" back.
Human Solution:
$27
There would be 21 working days in a March where the first weekday is the third.  The combination of wins in which anyone will have lost the most money has a total of 19 wins (10 for Kathy, 5 for Kevin and 4 for Kate).  In this scenario, Kate would have lost 15 times ($15) and won 4 times ($8), for a net loss of $7.  Since she now has $20, she must have started with $27.
Response:
Let  

 A = number of times Kate wins,  
 B = number of times Kevin wins,  
 C = number of times Kathy wins.  

From the statement  

 C = 2 B                (Kathy wins twice as often as Kevin)  
 B = A + 1              (Kevin wins once more than Kate)

Put A = x.  
Then B = x + 1 and C = 2x + 2.

Total winning days  
 W = A + B + C = x + (x + 1) + (2x + 2) = 4x + 3.

There are 21 weekday pools (from Mon. 3 Mar. to Mon. 31 Mar.).  
Hence 4x + 3 ≤ 21  ⇒ x ≤ 4,  so x = 0,1,2,3,4 are possible.

Money won or lost each time there is a winner  

 • winner nets +2 dollars (takes \$3 pot, put in \$1)  
 • each loser nets –1 dollar.  

Let ΔK, ΔT, ΔH be Kevin’s, Kate’s and Kathy’s net changes for the whole month.

 ΔK = 2B – (W – B) = 3B – W = 3(x + 1) – (4x + 3) = –x  
 ΔT = 2A – (W – A) = 3A – W = 3x – (4x + 3) = –x – 3  
 ΔH = 2C – (W – C) = 3C – W = 3(2x + 2) – (4x + 3) = 2x + 3

(ΔK + ΔT + ΔH = 0, as expected.)

Each person finishes with \$20, so the amounts they had on 3 March were  

 Kevin K₀ = 20 – ΔK = 20 + x  
 Kate  T₀ = 20 – ΔT = 20 + x + 3 = 23 + x  
 Kathy H₀ = 20 – ΔH = 20 – (2x + 3) = 17 – 2x

Because x ≤ 4, H₀ is never negative, so all these values are feasible.  
For each admissible x we get

 x = 0 : largest initial amount = 23  
 x = 1 : largest initial amount = 24  
 x = 2 : largest initial amount = 25  
 x = 3 : largest initial amount = 26  
 x = 4 : largest initial amount = 27

Thus the greatest possible amount anyone could have had in the desk on 3 March occurs when x = 4 (19 winning days: Kate 4, Kevin 5, Kathy 10, and 2 no-win days).  In that case Kate started with \$27, Kevin with \$24 and Kathy with \$9.

Therefore the largest amount that could have been sitting in any desk at the beginning of March is \$27.

Final answer: 27

Question:
Question: When world-famous Madadian philosopher Torks G'Arbage was imprisoned for being a disturbing influence and relieving himself in a public place, he was held in high esteem by his guards, many of whom had followed Torks' teachings. All four of the guards hoped that something would occur that would facilitate his escape. One evening, the guard who was on duty accidentally on purpose left the cell door open so that Torks G'Arbage could leave for distant parts.
Torks G'Arbage did not attempt to escape, as it was his philosophy that if you accept society's rules, you must also accept its punishments. However, the open door was considered by the Madadian authorities to be a serious matter. It was not clear which guard was on that evening. When questioned, the four guards made the following statements in their defence:
Norris McDim:
A) I did not leave the door open.
B) Morris was the one who did it.
Nobby Shifty:
A) I was not the one who was on duty that evening.
B) Norris was on duty.
Morris the Daft:
A) Nobby was the one on duty that evening.
B) I hoped Torks G'Arbage would escape.
Robby O'Mental:
A) I did not leave the door open.
B) I was not surprised that Torks G'Arbage did not attempt to escape.
Considering that, in total, three statements are true and five statements are false, which guard is guilty?
 Hint: nan
Human Solution:
Robby left the door open.
The one truth given is that all 4 guards hoped that Torks G'Arbage would escape, so statement B from Morris is a truth.
There are only 3 truthful statements.
If Norris had done it, then Nobby made 2 truthful statements and Robby's statement A would be true; making a total of 4 truths, so it can't be Norris.
If Nobby had done it, statement A from Norris would be true, both of Morris's statements would be true, and Robby's statement A would be true; again a total of 4, so it can't be Nobby.
If Morris had left the cell open, both of Norris's statements would be true, as would Nobby's statement A, Morris's statement B, and Robby's statement A; a total of 5 truths.
In Robby's case, in detail:
Norris A True
B False
Nobby A True
B False
Morris A False
B True
Dave A False
B False (why did he bother to leave the
cell door open?)
Response:
Let  

D = guard who was on duty that evening (and who therefore left the cell-door open).

For each guard write down his two statements and translate them into facts about D (the two “mental-state’’ statements will be dealt with later).

1. Norris McDim  
   A  :  I did not leave the door open        ⇔   D ≠ Norris  
   B  :  Morris was the one who did it       ⇔   D = Morris  

2. Nobby Shifty  
   A  :  I was not on duty that evening      ⇔   D ≠ Nobby  
   B  :  Norris was on duty                  ⇔   D = Norris  

3. Morris the Daft  
   A  :  Nobby was on duty                   ⇔   D = Nobby  
   B  :  I hoped Torks would escape          ⇔   H   (a fact about Morris’s hope)

4. Robby O’Mental  
   A  :  I did not leave the door open       ⇔   D ≠ Robby  
   B  :  I was not surprised Torks stayed    ⇔   S   (a fact about Robby’s surprise)

There are eight statements in all; the problem states that exactly three are true and five are false.

Extra information from the story  
“All four of the guards hoped that something would occur that would facilitate his escape.”  
So every guard, Morris included, hoped for the escape; therefore  

H = True.                                                                (1)

Now test each possible guard-on-duty.

Case 1.  D = Norris  
Truth values:  
Norris A (F), Norris B (F), Nobby A (T), Nobby B (T), Morris A (F), Robby A (T)  
So far 3 T and 3 F; the two remaining statements are Morris B (H) and Robby B (S).  
Because of (1) Morris B is True, giving already 4 true statements—too many.  
Hence D ≠ Norris.

Case 2.  D = Nobby  
Truth values:  
Norris A (T), Norris B (F), Nobby A (F), Nobby B (F), Morris A (T), Robby A (T)  
Again 3 T and 3 F before considering Morris B and Robby B.  
Morris B is True by (1), so we again get at least 4 true statements—too many.  
Hence D ≠ Nobby.

Case 3.  D = Morris  
Truth values:  
Norris A (T), Norris B (T), Nobby A (T), Nobby B (F), Morris A (F), Robby A (T)  
Already 4 true statements (and only two left to look at), impossible.  
Hence D ≠ Morris.

Case 4.  D = Robby  
Truth values:  
Norris A (T), Norris B (F), Nobby A (T), Nobby B (F), Morris A (F), Robby A (F)  
That is 2 T and 4 F so far.  
Morris B is True by (1), making 3 T and 4 F.  
To reach the required total of three true statements, Robby B must be false, i.e.  

S = False (Robby actually was surprised).  

This gives exactly 3 true and 5 false statements, satisfying all the conditions.

Since only this last case works, Robby O’Mental was the guard on duty and the one who left the door open.

Final answer: Robby O’Mental.

Question:
Question: John, Pete, Tom, George, and Steve are brothers. One day, one of them broke a window. When their father asked them who did it, they gave the following answers:
John: "It was Pete or Tom."
Pete: "It was neither George nor me."
Tom: "Both of you are lying."
Steve: "No, only one of them is lying."
George: "No, Steve, you are wrong."
Then their mother added: "Three of my sons are telling the truth, but I do not believe what the two others said."
Who broke the window?
 Hint: If you find it difficult to use logic alone, then use trial and error by assuming each one of the five sons broke the window, and list whether they are telling a lie or the truth.
Hint: If you find it difficult to use logic alone, then use trial and error by assuming each one of the five sons broke the window, and list whether they are telling a lie or the truth.
Human Solution: By assuming that each of the five brothers broke the window and seeing how many told the truth, only Tom can be the person who broke the window.
Response:
Let  

S₁ : “It was Pete or Tom.”                 (John)  
S₂ : “It was neither George nor me.”           (Pete)  
S₃ : “Both of you are lying.” (i.e. John is lying AND Pete is lying) (Tom)  
S₄ : “No, only one of them is lying.” (exactly one of S₁, S₂ is false) (Steve)  
S₅ : “No, Steve, you are wrong.” (¬S₄)           (George)  

Mother: “Exactly three of my sons are telling the truth.”

Step 1.  Observe the logical relations.

• S₄ is the statement “S₁ and S₂ have opposite truth values.”  
• S₅ says S₄ is false, so S₅ = ¬S₄.  
 Therefore S₄ and S₅ can never be both true or both false; exactly one of them is true.

Step 2.  Count truths.

Because S₄ and S₅ contribute one truth and one lie, the remaining three statements (S₁, S₂, S₃) must contribute two truths and one lie to make the required total of three truths.

Step 3.  Analyse S₃.

S₃ claims “S₁ is false AND S₂ is false.”

• If S₃ were true, then S₁ and S₂ would both be false.  
 That would make among {S₁, S₂, S₃} exactly one truth and two lies, contradicting the need for two truths.  
 Hence S₃ must be false.

Step 4.  Consequences of S₃ being false.

Since S₃ is false, the conjunction “S₁ false AND S₂ false” is false; therefore at least one of S₁, S₂ is true.

But we already need exactly two truths among {S₁, S₂, S₃}, and S₃ is false; thus both S₁ and S₂ must be true.

Step 5.  Evaluate S₄ and S₅.

Because S₁ and S₂ are both true, 0 of them are lying.  
• S₄ (“exactly one of them is lying”) is therefore false.  
• S₅ (¬S₄) is true.  

The truth distribution is now:

True : S₁, S₂, S₅  (3 truths)  
False: S₃, S₄    (2 lies)

This satisfies Mother’s condition.

Step 6.  Identify the culprit from S₁ and S₂ being true.

S₁ true  ⇒ the culprit is Pete or Tom.  
S₂ true  ⇒ the culprit is not Pete and not George.  

Combining these, the only possible culprit is Tom.

All statements are now consistent with the required truth pattern, so the assignment is valid.

Final answer: Tom broke the window.

Question:
Question: A telephone number has the form ABC-DEF-GHIJ, where each letter represents a different digit. The digits in each part of the number are in decreasing order; that is, ABC, DEF, and GHIJ. Furthermore, D, E, and F are consecutive even digits; G, H, I, and J are consecutive odd digits; and A+B+C=9. What is A?
 Hint: nan
Human Solution:
The consecutive even digits DEF can be 420, 642 or 864, while the consecutive odd digits GHIJ can be 7531 or 9753.
Since A+B+C=9, none of them can be 9, and GHIJ must be 9753, and one of A, B, C is 1.
The other two add up to 8, which is obtained by 8+0.
Therefore, A, the biggest number of the three, is 8.
Response:
Step 1  ‑  possible patterns for DEF  
D,E,F must be consecutive even digits in decreasing order.  
Even digits are 0,2,4,6,8, so the only possible triples are  
• 8-6-4  • 6-4-2  • 4-2-0

Step 2  ‑  possible patterns for GHIJ  
G,H,I,J must be four consecutive odd digits in decreasing order.  
Odd digits are 1,3,5,7,9, so the only possible quadruples are  
• 9-7-5-3  • 7-5-3-1

Step 3  ‑  choose DEF and GHIJ and see what is left for A,B,C  
A,B,C must be in decreasing order and satisfy A + B + C = 9.  
All ten digits must be different.

Case 1 : DEF = 8-6-4  
 a) GHIJ = 9-7-5-3 ⟹ remaining digits {0,1,2}.  Their largest possible sum is 3, < 9.  
 b) GHIJ = 7-5-3-1 ⟹ remaining digits {0,2,9}.  The only decreasing arrangement is 9-2-0, whose sum is 11 ≠ 9.  
 No solution here.

Case 2 : DEF = 6-4-2  
 a) GHIJ = 9-7-5-3 ⟹ remaining digits {0,1,8}.  
  The only decreasing triple is 8-1-0, and 8 + 1 + 0 = 9.  Perfect – this works.  
 b) GHIJ = 7-5-3-1 ⟹ remaining digits {0,8,9}.  No way to make a decreasing triple summing to 9.  
 So the only valid choice in this case is  ABC = 8-1-0.

Case 3 : DEF = 4-2-0  
 Try each GHIJ choice; in both sub-cases the remaining three digits cannot form a decreasing triple summing to 9.  
 Therefore no solution here either.

Step 4  ‑  assemble the unique valid telephone number  
ABC-DEF-GHIJ = 810-642-9753, using each digit 0–9 exactly once.  

Hence A = 8.

Final answer: 8

Question:
Question: I have 3 dads and 4 sisters. My immediate family (living in my house) consists of 7. Two of my sisters only have 2 dads. How is this possible?
 Hint: My nephew lives with me and I'm the middle child.
Hint: My nephew lives with me and I'm the middle child.
Human Solution: I have a biological dad, who I don't know. An adopted dad- my sisters' dad and a step dad- who lives with me. My two younger sisters never knew my biological dad. My oldest sister (19) lives by herself. Her son lives with me, my 3 other sisters, my mom, and step dad.
Response:
Let the people in the story be described in the order in which they arrived.

1.  Mum married Husband #1.  
    •  They had two girls, Ann and Beth.  

2.  Mum and Husband #1 divorced, but he has always stayed in the children’s lives and is still called “Dad” by anyone who wants to.

3.  Mum married Husband #2.  
    •  They had two more children, Carl (the narrator, the middle child) and Dana.  
    •  After some years Mum and Husband #2 also divorced.  Like Husband #1 he still visits often and is still “Dad” to the children who know him.

4.  Mum married Husband #3 (her present husband).  
    •  They had one more daughter, Eva.  
    •  Husband #3 lives elsewhere at the moment because of work, but he is very much part of the family and the children all call him “Dad” too.

Which “Dad(s)” each child has
•  Carl, Dana and Eva have all three men in their lives, so each of them quite naturally says “I have three dads.”  
•  Ann and Beth never regarded Husband #2 as a father-figure – he came after they had gone to live with their own dad for a while – so they see only Husband #1 (their biological father) and Husband #3 (their current step-dad) as dads.  Hence “only two dads.”

Who lives in the house now
•  Mum  
•  Ann (now a young adult)  
•  Beth  
•  Carl (the narrator)  
•  Dana  
•  Eva  
•  Ann’s little boy, Frank               ←  the nephew mentioned in the hint

That is 7 people living under the same roof, exactly as stated.

So:
•  Carl can truthfully say he has 3 dads.  
•  He really does have 4 sisters.  
•  Two of those sisters have only 2 dads.  
•  The household contains exactly 7 people, one of whom is his nephew.  

All conditions in the riddle are satisfied by a completely ordinary sequence of divorces, remarriages and an older sister who already has a child.

Final answer:  The children all share the same mother, but their mother has been married three times.  Each husband is still “Dad” to the children who know him, so the narrator and two of the girls have three dads (their own biological father plus two stepfathers), while the two oldest girls know only two of the men as fathers.  Counting Mum, the five children and the oldest girl’s baby, there are 7 people living in the house.

Question:
Question: There are three brothers: Al, Ben, and Carl. Two of the three brothers are boxers. Here are some facts:
1. The shorter of Al and Ben is the older boxer.
2. The younger of Ben and Carl is the shorter boxer.
3. The taller of Al and Carl is the younger boxer.
Which brother is not a boxer?
 Hint: nan
Human Solution:
Carl is not a boxer.
From fact 1, we know that Carl is not the older boxer.
From fact 3, we know that Ben is not the younger boxer.
We now have three possible scenarios:
1. Al is the younger boxer and Ben is the older boxer.
2. Ben is the older boxer and Carl is the younger boxer.
3. Al is the older boxer and Carl is the younger boxer.
If scenario 1 is true, fact 1 tells us that Ben is shorter than Al.
If scenario 2 is true, fact 1 tells us that Ben is shorter than Al; fact 3 tells us that Carl is taller than Al, making Ben shorter than Carl.
If scenario 3 is true, fact 3 tells us that Carl is taller than Al.
We can now expand our three scenarios:
1. Al is the younger, taller boxer, and Ben is the older, shorter boxer.
2. Ben is the older, shorter boxer, and Carl is the younger, taller boxer.
3. Al is the older, shorter boxer, and Carl is the younger, taller boxer.
Scenario 2 cannot be possible because it contradicts fact 2 by making the younger of Ben and Carl the taller boxer.
Fact 2 also tells us that Al is not the shorter boxer, so scenario 3 cannot be possible, either.
Therefore, scenario 1 is true, which means that Carl is not a boxer.
Response:
Let  

• OB  = the Older of the two boxers  
• YB  = the Younger of the two boxers  
• SB  = the Shorter of the two boxers  
• TB  = the Taller of the two boxers  

Because there are exactly two boxers, the four symbols OB, YB, SB, TB designate two distinct persons (OB ≠ YB and SB ≠ TB), but each symbol must be one of Al (A), Ben (B) or Carl (C).

Translate each statement.

1. “The shorter of Al and Ben is the older boxer.”
   ⇒ OB is the shorter of A and B.  
   Hence OB ∈ {A, B}.

2. “The younger of Ben and Carl is the shorter boxer.”
   ⇒ SB is the younger of B and C.  
   Thus SB ∈ {B, C} and the younger of B & C must be a boxer.

3. “The taller of Al and Carl is the younger boxer.”
   ⇒ YB is the taller of A and C.  
   Hence YB ∈ {A, C}.

Because OB and YB are different people, exactly one of the following three assignments of (OB, YB) is possible:

Case 1 OB = A, YB = C          (boxers A & C)  
Case 2 OB = B, YB = A          (boxers A & B)  
Case 3 OB = B, YB = C          (boxers B & C)

Examine each case in turn, keeping in mind that SB must be the younger of B and C.

––––––––––––––––––––––  
Case 1 (Boxers A & C, non-boxer B)

• OB = A is the shorter of A and B ⇒ A shorter than B.  
• YB = C is the taller of A and C  ⇒ C taller than A.  
So heights: C > A > B.

The younger of B and C is C, hence SB = C ⇒ C must be shorter than the other boxer (A).  
But C is already taller than A — a contradiction.  
Case 1 impossible.

––––––––––––––––––––––  
Case 2 (Boxers A & B, non-boxer C)

• OB = B is the shorter of A and B ⇒ B shorter than A.  
• YB = A is the taller of A and C  ⇒ A taller than C.  
So far heights: A > C ? > B, with B < A.

The younger of B and C must be a boxer; C is not a boxer, so B must be younger than C.
Statement 2 then gives SB = B, which also requires B be shorter than C.
Combining these: A > C > B in height and C > B > A in age.

All three original statements are now satisfied:
1. shorter(A,B)=B = OB (older boxer) ✔  
2. younger(B,C)=B = SB (shorter boxer) ✔  
3. taller(A,C)=A = YB (younger boxer) ✔  

Thus Case 2 is consistent.

––––––––––––––––––––––  
Case 3 (Boxers B & C, non-boxer A)

• OB = B is the shorter of A and B ⇒ B shorter than A.  
• YB = C is the taller of A and C  ⇒ C taller than A.  
So heights: C > A > B.

YB = C means C is younger than B, so the younger of B and C is C.  
Statement 2 demands this younger brother (C) be the shorter boxer, i.e. C shorter than B, contradicting C taller than A > B.  
Case 3 impossible.

––––––––––––––––––––––  

Only Case 2 works, in which Al and Ben are the two boxers and Carl is not.

Final answer: Carl

Question:
Question: Andy dislikes the catcher. Ed's sister is engaged to the second baseman. The center fielder is taller than the right fielder. Harry and the third baseman live in the same building. Paul and Allen each won $20 from the pitcher at pinochle. Ed and the outfielders play poker during their free time. The pitcher's wife is the third baseman's sister. The pitcher, catcher, and infielders except Allen, Harry, and Andy, are shorter than Sam. Paul, Andy, and the shortstop lost $50 each at the racetrack. Paul, Harry, Bill, and the catcher took a trouncing from the second baseman at pool. Sam is involved in a divorce suit. The catcher and the third baseman each have two children. Ed, Paul, Jerry, the right fielder, and the center fielder are bachelors. The others are married. The shortstop, the third baseman, and Bill each cleaned up $100 betting on the fight. One of the outfielders is either Mike or Andy. Jerry is taller than Bill. Mike is shorter than Bill. Each of them is heavier than the third baseman.
Using these facts, determine the names of the men playing the various positions on the baseball team.
 Hint: nan
Human Solution: Harry is the pitcher, Allen the catcher, Paul the first baseman, Jerry the second baseman, Andy the third baseman, Ed the shortstop, Sam the left fielder, Mike the right fielder, and Bill the center fielder.

Question:
Question: On Sunday, December 22, four Madadian cruise ships - W, X, Y, Z - started their series of winter cruises to various ports around Madadia.
Ship W left at 4:00 PM on Sunday, December 22, for a series of 8-days cruises to Madport.
Ship X left at 4:30 PM on Sunday, December 22, for a series of alternating 11-days and 13-days cruises to Adeville.
Ship Y left at 5:00 PM on Sunday, December 22, for a series of 5-days cruises to Kebabtown.
Ship Z left on Monday for a series of 7-days cruises.
Each ship is scheduled to return back early in the morning after the last day of the cruise and leave again late in the afternoon of the same day.
On how many days occasions between December 22 and February 28 will three ships be moored at the port?
 Hint: nan
Human Solution:
On no occasions (other than start date December 22) between December 22 and February 28, three ships will be moored at the port.
Find out the days on when each ship will be in port:
Ship W will be in port on days 1, 9, 17, 25, 33, 41, 49, 57 and 65.
Ship X will be in port on days 1, 12, 25, 36, 49, 60 and 73.
Ship Y will be in port on days 1, 6, 11, 16, 21, 26, 31, 36, 41, 46, 51, 56, 61 and 66.
Ship Z will be in port on days 1, 2, 9, 16, 23, 30, 37, 44, 51, 58 and 65.
From above data, it is clear that - on no occasion (other than December 22) will three ships be moored at the port.
Also, on 8 occasions, there will be 2 ships moored at the port.
Response:
Step 1 –  Clarify what “a n-day cruise” means  
The ships leave late in the afternoon of the departure day.  
They stay at sea for n whole days and return early in the morning of the following day
(the (n+1)-st day counted from the afternoon departure).  
That return-and-turn-round day is the only day on which the ship is moored, and the
next cruise starts late that same afternoon.  
Hence the interval between two successive “mooring days’’ of a ship that always sails
an n-day cruise is (n+1) days.

Step 2 –  List the mooring days for each ship, numbering the calendar days
Day 0 = Sunday 22 December  
Day 1 = Monday 23 December  
…  
Day 68 = Friday 28 February

Ship W : 8-day cruises → interval 9 days, first mooring day 0  
W-days : 0, 9, 18, 27, 36, 45, 54, 63  

Ship X : alternating 11- and 13-day cruises – take the first cruise to be 11 days  
Intervals : 12, 14, 12, 14, …, first mooring day 0  
X-days : 0, 12, 26, 38, 52, 64  

Ship Y : 5-day cruises → interval 6 days, first mooring day 0  
Y-days : 0, 6, 12, 18, 24, 30, 36, 42, 48, 54, 60, 66  

Ship Z : 7-day cruises; first departure is Monday 23 December ⇒ first mooring day 1  
Z-days : 1, 9, 17, 25, 33, 41, 49, 57, 65  

Step 3 –  Count the number of ships moored on every day 0 … 68

Day 0 : W, X, Y  → 3 ships  
Day 1 : Z  
Day 6 : Y  
Day 9 : W, Z  
Day 12: X, Y  
Day 17: Z  
Day 18: W, Y  
Day 24: Y  
Day 25: Z  
Day 26: X  
Day 27: W  
Day 30: Y  
Day 33: Z  
Day 36: W, Y  
Day 38: X  
Day 41: Z  
Day 42: Y  
Day 45: W  
Day 48: Y  
Day 49: Z  
Day 52: X  
Day 54: W, Y  
Day 57: Z  
Day 60: Y  
Day 63: W  
Day 64: X  
Day 65: Z  
Day 66: Y  

At every listed day (and at every day not shown) the number of ships in port is
either 1 or 2, except for Day 0 where it is 3.

Step 4 –  Conclusion  
Only once – on Sunday morning, 22 December – are three (and only three) of the four
ships simultaneously moored at the port between 22 December and 28 February.

Final answer: 1

Question:
Question: Henry and Gretchen are going to play a game.  Henry explains, "You and I will take turns saying numbers.  The first person will say a number between 1 and 10.  Then the other person will say a number that is at least 1 higher than that number, and at most 10 higher.  We will keep going back and forth in this way until one of us says the number 50.  That person wins.  I'll start."
"Not so fast!" says Gretchen.  "I want to win, so I will start."
What number should Gretchen say to start?
 Hint: By following this strategy, she is assured a victory.  Think of all of the numbers she will want to say.
Hint: By following this strategy, she is assured a victory.  Think of all of the numbers she will want to say.
Human Solution:
She wants to say, "6."
The series of numbers she will say is 6, 17, 28, 39, 50.
Since she wants to say 50, she needs Henry to say a number between 40 and 49.  Therefore, she wants to say 39.
Knowing she wants to say 39, she needs Henry to say a number between 29 and 38.  So she wants to say 28.  Following this same logic recursively, she will want to say 17, and she will want to say 6 to start the game, and be assured victory.
Response:
Step 1 –  Rephrase the rules in “total-so-far” language  
Instead of “saying a number”, think of the players as keeping a running total that starts at 0.  
• On a turn a player adds any integer from 1 through 10 to the current total.  
• Whoever makes the total exactly 50 wins.

Step 2 –  Backwards analysis: look for the “cold” (losing) totals  
Call a position (current total) losing if, when it is your turn at that total, perfect play forces you to lose.  
Work backwards from the winning total 50.

• If the total is 49-40 you can add 1-10 to hit 50, so 40-49 are winning positions.  
• Therefore the total 39 is losing: whatever you add (1-10) hands your opponent a total in 40-49, from which the opponent wins next turn.  

Now continue backwards.  From 39 you can move to 29-38, all of which are winning (they can jump to 39).  
Hence 28 is losing.  

One more step: from 28 you can move to 18-27, all winning, so 17 is losing.  

Again: from 17 you can move to 7-16, all winning, so 6 is losing.  

We now have the whole chain of losing positions:  
6, 17, 28, 39 (and of course 50 where the game ends).  
Notice they are exactly the numbers that are congruent to 6 mod 11.

Step 3 –  The winning strategy that uses those numbers  
If you can hand your opponent one of the losing totals 6, 17, 28 or 39, you are guaranteed to win: after any reply (they must add 1-10), you can always add just enough to reach the next number in the list, eventually finishing with 50.  Concretely, you keep the pair of moves (yours plus your opponent’s) adding up to 11.

Step 4 –  Gretchen’s first move  
Gretchen is making the very first move, so the running total is 0.  
To force Henry into a losing position immediately, she herself must announce the first losing total: 6.

After that her replies are easy.  Whatever Henry adds (1-10), Gretchen adds the complementary number that makes the two moves sum to 11, thereby moving the total successively to 17, 28, 39, and finally 50.

Therefore Gretchen is assured of victory if she starts by saying

Final answer: 6

Question:
Question: One of four people - two men (Jack and Mike) and two women (Carol and Lily) - was murdered.
The following facts refer to the people mentioned:
(a) Jack's sister argued exactly once with Carol's legal husband after the murder.
(b) Mike's sister argued twice with the victim's legal spouse after the murder. Who was the victim?
 Hint: nan
Human Solution:
Mike is the victim.
If Mike's sister and Jack's sister are the same person, then (a) reads "Lily argued exactly once with (Mike or Jack)" and (b) reads "Lily argued twice with (the same Mike or Jack)".  These two statements contradict each other.  Therefore Mike's sister must be different from Jack's sister.
If this is the case then there are two possibilities:
1)  Jack and Carol are brother and sister.  Mike and Lily are brother and sister.  Jack is married to Lily and Mike is married to Carol.  If this is the case, then (a) reads "Carol argued once with Mike" and (b) reads "Lily argued twice with herself", leaving Jack dead.  Since Lily did not likely argue with herself, this is not the solution.
2)  Jack and Lily are brother and sister.  Mike and Carol are brother and sister.  Jack is married to Carol and Lily is married to Mike.  If this is the case, then (a) reads "Lily argued once with Jack" and (b) reads "Carol argued twice with Lily", leaving Mike dead.  Since there are no contradictions, this is the solution.
Response:
Let  

J = Jack (male)  
M = Mike (male)  
C = Carol (female)  
L = Lily (female)

All husbands and wives are chosen from this set (the usual assumption in such puzzle-stories) and no one is married to a blood relative (no incest).

1.  “Jack’s sister argued exactly once with Carol’s legal husband.”
    • Jack’s sister is a woman – either C or L.  
    • Carol’s husband is a man – either J or M.  
    • So there is one (and only one) quarrel between Jack’s sister and Carol’s husband.

2.  “Mike’s sister argued twice with the victim’s legal spouse.”
    • Mike’s sister is also a woman – either C or L.  
    • The victim’s spouse is alive, so that person is one of the other three.  
    • There are exactly two quarrels between Mike’s sister and that spouse.

Because the two quarrel counts (one quarrel vs. two quarrels) are different, the two ordered pairs
   (Jack’s sister , Carol’s husband)   and   (Mike’s sister , victim’s spouse)
cannot be the same pair of people; otherwise they would have quarreled both once and twice, an impossibility.

----------------------------------------------------------------
Step 1.  Decide the marriages (two possibilities).

(A)  J–C and M–L  (Carol married to Jack, Lily married to Mike).  
(B)  J–L and M–C  (Lily married to Jack, Carol married to Mike).

----------------------------------------------------------------
Step 2.  Work through each marriage pattern.

Marriage pattern (A):  J–C, M–L
-------------------------------------------------
• Carol’s husband is J.  
• Therefore Jack’s sister must be L (otherwise Jack would have quarreled with himself).  
  ⇒  L argued once with J.                                     (1)

For Mike, his sister can only be the remaining woman, C.  
• So Mike’s sister is C.  
• If the victim were J, C would have to quarrel twice with J’s spouse C – i.e. quarrel with herself. Impossible.  
  ⇒  The victim is not J.  
• Let the victim be M.  His spouse is L.  
  ⇒  C quarreled twice with L.                                  (2)

Everything is consistent, with no incest.  In this pattern the victim is M.

Marriage pattern (B):  J–L, M–C
-------------------------------------------------
• Carol’s husband is now M.  
• Hence Jack’s sister must be C (so that she can quarrel with M, not with herself).  
  ⇒  C argued once with M.                                     (1′)

The only woman left for “Mike’s sister” is L.  
• Mike’s sister is L.  
• If the victim were J, L would have to quarrel twice with J’s spouse L – a quarrel with herself. Impossible.  
  ⇒  The victim is not J.  
• Let the victim be M.  His spouse is C.  
  ⇒  L quarreled twice with C.                                  (2′)

Again everything is consistent and there is no incest.  The victim is M.

----------------------------------------------------------------
Step 3.  Conclusion.

Both logically possible, non-incestuous arrangements lead to the same result:  
Mike must be the murder victim.

Final answer: Mike

Question:
Question: Walter, Xavier, Yoshi, and Zeke crossed a river in a tiny rowboat. They all started on the same side of the river. They made three trips from the starting side to the destination side, and two trips from the destination side to the starting side. Here are some facts:
1. On each trip from the starting side of the river to the destination side, two people were in the boat, but only one person rowed the boat, and that person rowed the boat for the entire trip.
2. On each return trip, only one person was in the boat.
3. Walter is the weakest of the group. He could only row the boat if no one else is in it.
4. Xavier is the second weakest of the group. He can only row the boat if he is by himself or if Yoshi, the lightest of the group, is a passenger.
5. Each man rowed the boat at least once.
Who rowed twice?
 Hint: nan
Human Solution:
Yoshi rowed twice.
Fact 5 tells us that Walter had to row the boat at least once, but fact 3 tells us that he had to go by himself. This means he could only row the boat on a return trip, which means he rowed on at least one return trip.
The man who rowed twice could not have rowed on two trips from the starting side to the destination side, because he would have had to make a third trip by himself back to the starting side. So the man who rowed twice must have made a return trip at least once.
Now we know that if Walter made two trips, they must both have been return trips, and Xavier, Yoshi, and Zeke each rowed for one of the other three trips. If Walter made only one trip, the other person who made a return trip must have been the person who rowed twice (Xavier, Yoshi, or Zeke) and that person would also have made one of the other three trips. So the three trips from the starting side to the destination side must have been rowed by Xavier, Yoshi, and Zeke.
Fact 1 tells us that Xavier's trip to the destination side must have had a passenger, and fact 4 tells us that that passenger must have been Yoshi. Yoshi would have had to row back to row his trip to the destination side, or else Yoshi rowed to the destination side, then back to the start, then got rowed across by Xavier.

Question:
Question: There is a famous diamond displayed in a room that measures 15 meters by 15 meters by 15 meters. The room is made entirely of concrete blocks and the floor is covered with a thick carpet. The only thing in the room is the diamond that is housed under a glass cube. The glass cube stands on a one-meter pedestal in the centre of the room. Alarm wires spaced eight centimetres apart and running parallel to each other lie under the carpet. The alarm will trigger if more than four kilograms of pressure is applied to any individual wire. Will Carlo who weighs 74 kilograms was able to steal the famous diamond using the following equipment: a five meter 2 x 4 board, four leather straps (each two meters long and five cm wide), a hammer, and a saw. How could he do it without triggering the alarm?
 Hint: nan
Human Solution: Will Carlo stole the diamond in the following manner: First, he cut five meter 2 x 4 boards in half. Then using the available straps, he fastened the two boards to his feet like skies. With the boards strapped to his feet, his weight was displacing enough so that he did not exceed the wire's weight tolerance and triggers the alarm. Carlo then slowly and carefully walked to the centre of the room, smashed the glass cube with the hammer, took the diamond and returned the same way he came in.
Response:
The alarm does not react to the total weight that is on the floor, it reacts to the pressure that any one of the parallel wires receives.  
A wire is 8 cm (0.08 m) away from its neighbours and it trips when it is loaded with more than 4 kg.

1.  How many wires can a 5-metre board cover?  
    5 m / 0.08 m ≈ 62.5 → 62 wires.

2.  If Will (74 kg) stands on such a board and the board lies ​across​ the wires (i.e. at right angles to them), his weight is divided among roughly 62 wires.  
    Load per wire ≈ 74 kg / 62 ≈ 1.2 kg < 4 kg.  
    Hence the alarm will not trigger while he is on the board; the same is true even if he is standing near one end – the board is stiff enough that the weight still spreads over a few dozen wires, keeping every individual load safely below 4 kg.

3.  The room is 15 m × 15 m; the diamond is in the centre, 7.5 m from any wall.  
    One 5-m board is therefore not long enough to reach the pedestal in a single span, but it is plenty long enough to let him “walk” it forward.

How Will does it

•   He lays the 5-m 2×4 flat on the carpet perpendicular to the alarm wires, steps onto the end that is nearest the door, and stands there.  
•   While his weight is safely supported, he lifts the rear end of the board, swings it forward and sets it down farther into the room.  
•   He walks to the new front end and repeats the operation.  
    Each “stride” moves the board almost its whole length, so after two complete moves he has advanced just under 10 m; a third move puts him beside the pedestal in the centre (≈7.5 m from the wall).

The leather straps are useful only for balance – he can loop one round his waist and the board when he has to bend down and pick the back end up – but they are not strictly necessary. The hammer (or the hammer head wrapped in carpet) is used to break the glass cover; the saw is never needed.

With the diamond in a pocket he makes the three board-moves in reverse and reaches the door, having never loaded any single wire with more than about 1¼ kg.

Final answer: He places the 5-metre board cross-wise on the floor, stands on it, and “walks” it forward in three instalments, each time lifting the back end and setting it down in front. Because the board always rests simultaneously on more than sixty wires, no wire ever bears more than ≈1.2 kg, far below the 4 kg trip limit, so the alarm never goes off while he enters, removes the diamond, and leaves.

Question:
Question: One day, in baking class, 15 students were baking cakes when the fire alarm went off. Everyone exited the building, but when they got back, they found someone had dumped all the sugar into two of the batter-filled bowls. Everyone was puzzled over what to do until Alice had an idea: why not mix the batters together and then separate the contents back in the bowls. Here is what happened in chronological order:
Alice mixed with Flare
June pours some into Emma's
Luke mixed with Callie
June mixed with Gabbi
Flare mixed with Gabbi
Watt mixed with Tina
Flare mixed with Tina
Luke mixed with Flare
Gabbi mixed with Callie
Daniel, Emma, & Alice mixed with each other
Oscar mixed with Quinn
Misty mixed with Callie
Alice, Misty, & Oscar mixed with each other
Tina mixed with Emma
Kaleb mixed with Quinn
June mixed with Daniel
Luke mixed with June
Ryan, Luke, & Watt mixed with each other
Callie, Alice, & Flare mixed with each other
Kaleb pours some into Daniel's
Watt mixed with Ryan
Watt pours some into Kaleb's
Daniel mixed with Luke
Misty mixed with Gabbi
Kaleb mixed with Tina
Emma & Quinn had no sugar; which 2 bowls started with sugar?
Everyone was able to figure it out.
 Hint: Everyone was able to figure it out.
Hint: Everyone was able to figure it out.
Human Solution:
Luke & Callie
To start, it can't be Emma or Quinn or anyone who mixed/gave to them. This leaves Flare, Luke, Callie, Gabbi, Watt, Misty, and Ryan.
It can't be Flare because he exchanged with Alice before Alice exchanged with Emma. It can't be Watt because he mixed with Tina before Tina exchanged with Emma. This leaves Luke, Callie, Gabbi, Misty, and Ryan.
It can't be Gabbi because she mixed with Flare before Flare mixed with Tina who mixed with Emma later. This leaves Luke, Callie, Misty, and Ryan.
If only one of Luke & Callie started with sugar it wouldn't be solvable because no interactions happened before them and the outcome would be the same, therefore the solution is either Misty and Ryan or Luke and Callie.
However, it can't be Ryan and Misty because they can't give June sugar!

Question:
Question: Hans Ernest Froopaloop, Jr. will marry one of three women: Audrey, Brenda, and Charlotte. Here are some facts:
1. Of Audrey and Brenda:
a. Either they both have blue eyes or neither has blue eyes.
b. One has red hair and the other does not.
2. Of Audrey and Charlotte:
a. Either they both have red hair or neither has red hair.
b. One is 5'11" and the other is not.
3. Of Brenda and Charlotte:
a. One has blue eyes and the other does not.
b. One is 5'11" and the other is not.
4. Of the three characteristics; blue eyes, red hair and 5'11":
a. If any of the three women has exactly two of the three characteristics, Mr. Froopaloop will marry the one with the least number of characteristics.
b. If any of the three women has exactly one of the three characteristics, Mr. Froopaloop will marry the one with the greatest number of characteristics.
Who will Mr. Froopaloop marry?
 Hint: nan
Human Solution:
Mr. Froopaloop will marry Charlotte.
Facts 1a and 3a tell us that Charlotte is either the only one with blue eyes or the only one without blue eyes. Facts 1b and 2a tell us that Brenda is either the only one with red hair or the only one without red hair. Facts 2b and 3b tell us that Charlotte is either the only one who is 5'11" or the only one who isn't 5'11". Fact 4 tells us that no one woman can have one characteristic while another has two characteristics. This gives us two scenarios:
1. Audrey has blue eyes, does not have red hair, and is 5'11". Brenda has blue eyes, red hair, and is 5'11". Charlotte does not have blue eyes, does not have red hair, and is not 5'11".
2. Audrey does not have blue eyes, has red hair, and is not 5'11". Brenda does not have blue eyes, does not have red hair, and is not 5'11". Charlotte has blue eyes, red hair, and is 5'11".
Fact 4a tells us that in scenario 1, Mr. Froopaloop will marry Charlotte. Fact 4b tells us that in scenario 2, Mr. Froopaloop will marry...Charlotte.
Response:
Let the three characteristics be  

B : blue-eyed  
R : red-haired  
H : 5′11″ tall  

Give each woman a 1 for a characteristic she has and 0 for a characteristic she does not have.

Write Audrey’s triple as (bA , rA , hA), Brenda’s as (bB , rB , hB) and Charlotte’s as (bC , rC , hC).

Translate the eight given facts:

1.  bA = bB                                      (1a)  
    rA ≠ rB                                      (1b)

2.  rA = rC                                      (2a)  
    hA ≠ hC                                      (2b)

3.  bB ≠ bC                                      (3a)  
    hB ≠ hC                                      (3b)

From (1a) and (3a)              bA = bB ≠ bC.  
From (1b) and (2a)              rA = rC ≠ rB.  
From (2b) and (3b)              hA = hB ≠ hC.

Introduce three independent binary variables

X = bA (the common eye-colour of Audrey & Brenda)  
Y = rA (the common hair-colour of Audrey & Charlotte)  
Z = hC (Charlotte’s height)

Then

Audrey     A = (X , Y , 1–Z)  
Brenda     B = (X , 1–Y , 1–Z)  
Charlotte  C = (1–X , Y , Z)

Number of characteristics each woman possesses:

fA = X + Y + (1 – Z)  
fB = X + (1 – Y) + (1 – Z) = X – Y – Z + 2  
fC = (1 – X) + Y + Z = 1 – X + Y + Z.

Now apply Mr. Froopaloop’s choice rule.

• Rule 4a applies iff some woman has exactly two characteristics, and in that case he marries the woman with the fewest characteristics.  
• Rule 4b applies iff some woman has exactly one characteristic, and in that case he marries the woman with the most characteristics.

Both rules must not be triggered simultaneously (otherwise the instruction would be contradictory), so a valid assignment must contain 2’s but no 1’s, or 1’s but no 2’s.

Examine the eight possible (X,Y,Z):

                    (X,Y,Z)        (fA,fB,fC)  
(0,0,0)   → (1,2,1)        both 1’s and 2’s  (invalid)  
(0,0,1)   → (0,1,2)        both 1’s and 2’s  (invalid)  
(0,1,0)   → (2,1,2)        both 1’s and 2’s  (invalid)  
(0,1,1)   → (1,0,3)        only 1’s → Rule 4b ⇒ marry C  
(1,0,0)   → (2,3,0)        only 2’s → Rule 4a ⇒ marry C  
(1,0,1)   → (1,2,1)        both 1’s and 2’s  (invalid)  
(1,1,0)   → (3,2,1)        both 1’s and 2’s  (invalid)  
(1,1,1)   → (2,1,2)        both 1’s and 2’s  (invalid)

Only two assignments avoid a contradiction, and in both of them Mr. Froopaloop marries Charlotte.

Therefore, no matter which admissible combination of characteristics the three women actually have, the rules force Hans Ernest Froopaloop, Jr. to pick Charlotte.

Final answer: Charlotte

Question:
Question: Draw a diagram of the Fantasylands to help you with this teaser...
Beethoven's Wig has been stolen again!  Instead of hiding it in a box, the enemy, who remains anonymous, has hidden it inside one of four castles.  Each castle is located in a different fantasyland and has a creature guarding its gates.  Use the clues below to put the lands in order (1st,2nd,3rd, and 4th), figure out which castle belongs in which land, which creature belong to which castle, and help Beethoven reclaim his wig!
Object: Beethoven's Wig
Fantasylands: Lothlorien, Mordor, Narnia, and Malacandra.
Creatures: Dragon, Troll, Giant, and Balrog.
Castles: Stone, Gold, Glass, and Silver.
1.  Narnia is to the left of Lothlorien, which is to the right of the Balrog.
2.  The Stone Castle is to the right of the Wig, and is placed at either Malacandra or Lothlorien.
3.  The Giant is not at Lothlorien and is not in the same place as the wig.
4.  The Balrog is not in Lothlorien, but he stays at the Stone Castle.
5.  The Troll doesn't live at the Golden Castle, which is to the left of where the Balrog stays and to the right of the Silver Castle.
6.  Mordor is to the left of the Dragon, who stays at the second place.
7.  The Troll is not at the Silver Castle, which is 1 fantasyland to the left of the wig.
 Hint: nan
Human Solution:
Mordor is the first fantasyland.  It contains the Giant and the Silver Castle.
Narnia is the second land.  It has the Dragon, the Golden Castle, and the Wig.
Malacandra is the third land.  It has the Stone Castle and the Balrog.
Lothlorien is the fourth land.  It contains the Troll and the Glass Castle.
Response:
Let the four positions be 1 (left-most) … 4 (right-most).  
Each position has exactly one land, one castle, one creature; somewhere the Wig is hidden.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
1.  From clue 6: the Dragon is at the 2nd place → creature(2)=Dragon.  
    Mordor is to the left of the Dragon → land(1)=Mordor.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
2.  Clue 4 says the Balrog stays at the Stone Castle, and he is
    not in Lothlorien.  
    Clue 2 adds that the Stone Castle is either in Malacandra or
    Lothlorien and is to the right of the Wig.  
    Therefore Stone Castle ≠ Lothlorien → Stone Castle = Malacandra.
    So

            castle = Stone   land = Malacandra   creature = Balrog

    occupy the same (so-far unknown) position.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
3.  Clue 5: Silver Castle < Golden Castle < Balrog-(Stone).  
    Thus the Balrog cannot be in position 1 (nothing is left of 1)
    and cannot be in position 2 (only one site is left of 2 and we
    need two).  Two possibilities remain:

        a) Balrog at position 3  (Silver 1, Gold 2, Balrog 3)  
        b) Balrog at position 4  (several sub-orders possible).

--------------------------------------------------------------------
4.  Test case (b) Balrog at 4.
    Clue 1 says Lothlorien is to the right of the Balrog.
    With the Balrog already at the extreme right this is impossible.
    ⇒  (b) is rejected.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
5.  Therefore Balrog is at position 3.  The castles to its left must
    be Silver (1) and Gold (2):

        pos 1 : Silver Castle  
        pos 2 : Golden Castle  
        pos 3 : Stone Castle (Balrog)  
        pos 4 : ‑-- (only Glass remains later)

--------------------------------------------------------------------
6.  Silver Castle is “1 fantasyland to the left of the Wig” (clue 7),
    hence Wig is at position 2.  
    The Stone Castle (pos 3) is to the right of the Wig (clue 2); OK.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
7.  Lands with the Balrog known (Malacandra at 3) use clue 1 again:
       • Lothlorien is to the right of the Balrog → land(4)=Lothlorien.  
       • Narnia is to the left of Lothlorien → Narnia must be position 2
         (position 1 is already Mordor).  

    The only land still unused is Malacandra, already fixed at position 3.
    So the lands are:

        1  Mordor  2  Narnia  3  Malacandra  4  Lothlorien

--------------------------------------------------------------------
8.  Creatures still undecided: Giant, Troll (Dragon & Balrog fixed).

    • Giant is “not at Lothlorien and not with the Wig” (clue 3).  
      Lothlorien is pos 4 and the Wig is pos 2, leaving positions 1 or 3.
      Position 3 already has Balrog, so Giant must be position 1.

    • Troll is “not at the Golden Castle” (2) and “not at the Silver
      Castle” (1) (clue 5 and 7).  Only position 4 remains → Troll at 4.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
9.  The only castle still unassigned is Glass, so castle(4)=Glass.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
Everything now fits every clue, giving one consistent arrangement:

Position 1 (left-most)  
 Land: Mordor Castle: Silver Creature: Giant

Position 2  
 Land: Narnia Castle: Golden Creature: Dragon (Gigantic Wig hidden here)

Position 3  
 Land: Malacandra Castle: Stone Creature: Balrog

Position 4 (right-most)  
 Land: Lothlorien Castle: Glass Creature: Troll

--------------------------------------------------------------------
Final answer:  
Mordor–Silver–Giant; Narnia–Golden–Dragon (with the Wig); Malacandra–Stone–Balrog; Lothlorien–Glass–Troll.

Question:
Question: Just before the end of the term four high school students were discussing their chances for certain grades. The following remarks contain the gist of their hopes and fears.
Jack: We'll all get different grades. If I get an A, then Lucy will get a D.
Jean: If Lucy gets a C, then Jack will get a D. Jack will get a better grade than Paul.
Lucy: If Jean doesn't get an A, then Jack will get a C. If I get a B, then Paul won't get a D.
Paul: If Lucy gets an A, then I'll get a B. if Jean doesn't get a B, I won't either.
When the final examinations were graded and the term marks made out each of the four passed, and strange as it may seem, each received a grade that checked exactly with all the ideas they had previously expressed.
What grade did each receive?
 Hint: nan
Human Solution: Jack, Jean, Lucy, and Paul received B, A, D, and C, respectively.
Response:
Let

 J  = Jack’s grade  
 Je = Jean’s grade  
 L  = Lucy’s grade  
 P  = Paul’s grade.

Possible grades are A, B, C, D and (by Jack’s first remark) all four must be different.

Translate every remark into a logical condition.

1.  All four grades are different.                 (1)

2.  Jack: If J = A then L = D.                  (2)

3.  Jean: If L = C then J = D.                  (3)
           J is better than P, i.e. J ≺ P in the order A < B < C < D. (4)

4.  Lucy:  If Je ≠ A then J = C.                 (5)
           If L = B then P ≠ D.                  (6)

5.  Paul:  If L = A then P = B.                  (7)
           If Je ≠ B then P ≠ B.                 (8)

We need one assignment of the four different letters A–D that makes every
implication true.

Step 1.  Jack cannot have A.

If J = A, (2) forces L = D.  
With L = D, (3) has false antecedent, so is fine.  
But (5) now has true antecedent (because Je ≠ A for any still-available grade), forcing J = C, contradicting J = A.  
Hence J ≠ A.

Step 2.  Try J = C.

Then (4) requires P = D (C is better only than D).  
The still-unused grades A and B go to Je and L.

Condition (6) forbids L = B (because P = D), so L = A and Je = B.

But (7) with L = A would force P = B, contradicting P = D.  
So J = C is impossible.

Step 3.  Try J = B.

Since J = B, (5) can be satisfied only if its antecedent is false; hence Je must be A (Je ≠ A would force J = C).  
Condition (4) says J is better than P, so P must be C or D.

Clause (3) tells us L cannot be C (otherwise J would have to be D), so L = D and P = C.

Check the remaining implications:

(2)  J ≠ A ⇒ antecedent false – OK.  
(3)  L = D ⇒ antecedent false – OK.  
(6)  L ≠ B ⇒ antecedent false – OK.  
(7)  L ≠ A ⇒ antecedent false – OK.  
(8)  Je ≠ B is true, and P ≠ B (P = C), so (8) is satisfied.

All statements are now true and all four grades are different.  
No other value for J works, so this is the unique solution.

Thus

 Jean received A  
 Jack received B  
 Paul received C  
 Lucy received D

Final answer: Jean – A, Jack – B, Paul – C, Lucy – D

Question:
Question: Mad Ade has placed five Queens on a chessboard, such that every square including those occupied by the Queens are under attack.
Imagine the chessboard is set out with reference points 1 to 8 on the vertical and A to H across the horizontal.
At what positions would the five Queens need to be?
 Hint: nan

Question: You are stuck in a room. All that is there is a slip of paper on a table, and many bottles. The only exit is guarded by a heat sensor that will not let you out. The only way out is to drink one of the bottles' contents, and the liquid will cool down your body heat (with no harm to yourself) enough so that the heat sensor doesn't detect you anymore. There are nine bottles on the ground beyond the table. The content of the slip of paper will tell you what each of the bottles are. Find out what all the bottles are, and then find out which one to drink to get out.
Three of me are poison, and will kill you if you drink.
Two of me are water, nothing bad will happen with these.
Two of me are wine, and it will only get you drunk.
One will heat you up forever, and this room will never let you out. (hinder)
Only one here will help you, it will cool down your body heat.
No medium bottles are poison.
Wine is bad in large doses, so none are large.
Each of the end bottles have the same contents.
No matter how help hides, it will be on poison's left side, but its left side is safe.
No two small bottles are the same.
The hinderer is harder, for it resides between wine and water.
The hinder bottle is large, so it works forever.
Neither big nor medium will save your life.
Poison is all you will get from the bottle on the far right.
Water is next to the helper.
Bottle Order:
Large--Small--Large--Medium--Small--Large--Medium--Large--Small
 Hint: nan
Human Solution:
Poison--wine--hinder--water--help--poison--wine--water--poison
Only the middle bottle will save your life.
Response:
Reasoning  
We label the nine places from left to right 1–9 and note the given sizes.

Place : 1   2   3   4   5   6   7   8   9  
Size  : L   S   L   M   S   L   M   L   S  

Symbols  
P = poison, W = water, V = wine, H = hinder (heats you), C = helper (cools you).

1.  “Poison is all you will get from the bottle on the far right”  →  9 = P.  
    “Each of the end bottles have the same contents”  → 1 = P.

2.  “No medium bottles are poison”  → 4,7 ≠ P.  
3.  “Wine is bad in large doses, so none are large”  → 1,3,6,8 (all large) ≠ V.  
4.  “The hinder bottle is large”  → H is at 3, 6 or 8 (the only large bottles not yet fixed).  
5.  “The hinderer … resides between wine and water”  
        • If H were at 8 its neighbours would be 7 (M) and 9 (P) – impossible.  
        • If H were at 6 its neighbours would be 5 (S) and 7 (M) – both could be wine & water, so possible.  
        • If H were at 3 its neighbours would be 2 (S) and 4 (M) – also possible.  
   Keep both 3 and 6 for the moment.

6.  “No matter how help hides, it will be on poison's left side, but its left side is safe.”  
    So we must have   safe – C – P   in consecutive places.  
7.  “Water is next to the helper.”  
    Safe bottle beside C is therefore water, giving  Water – C – Poison.  
8.  “Neither big nor medium will save your life.”  →  C must be Small.  
    Small positions are 2,5,9; but 9 is poison and 2’s right-hand neighbour (3) is not poison in every case,   
    so C must be at 5, with Water at 4 and Poison at 6:  4=W, 5=C, 6=P.

   Now H cannot be at 6 (it is poison), so H = 3.  
   Since H is between wine and water, places 2 and 4 must be Wine and Water in some order; 4 is already Water, so 2 = Wine.

9.  Count totals so far  
        P : 1,6,9 (three)        OK  
        W : 4 (one)  
        V : 2 (one)  
        H : 3  
        C : 5  
   Still missing: one Water and one Wine.  The remaining undecided places are 7 (Medium) and 8 (Large).  
   Medium cannot be poison and wine cannot be large, so  
        7 = Wine, 8 = Water.

10.  Check every clue – all satisfied.

Final catalogue  

Place : 1     2     3      4      5      6     7      8      9  
Size  : L     S     L      M      S      L     M      L      S  
Content: P   V     H     W     C     P     V     W     P  

The only cooling (“helper”) bottle is the 5th, a small bottle in the middle.

Final answer: Drink the fifth bottle (the small one in the middle); it is the only cooling potion.

Question:
Question: You have the following equations:
a + c = a
b - c = c
c / b = c
a * a = b
You also know that a, b, c have the values 0, 1 and 2, but not necessarily in that order.
But to make matters more complicated the symbols + - * / have been mixed up: all you know is that each represents a different arithmetical operation (addition, subtraction, multiplication or division).
Can you work out the values of a, b and c, and what each of the symbols actually mean?
 Hint: The only thing you should assume about the arithmetical symbols is that no two represent the same operation.
Hint: The only thing you should assume about the arithmetical symbols is that no two represent the same operation.
Human Solution:
a = 1
b = 2
c = 0
+ = -
- = *
* = +
/ = /
(Yes, the division symbol escaped the bedlam!)
Response:
Let  

• the three letters a, b, c be the three different numbers 0, 1, 2  
• the four symbols +, –, *, / each stand for one of the four elementary operations, all different from each other.

We must satisfy the four given “equations”

(1) a + c = a  
(2) b – c = c  
(3) c / b = c  
(4) a * a = b

Step 1 – decide whether c can be 0.  
If c = 0, equation (2) becomes b – 0 = 0.  
This is only automatically true when the symbol “–” is multiplication (because b×0=0 for every b).  
So we set
  –  ≡  ×.

Step 2 – work out what “/” must be.  
With c = 0, equation (3) reads 0 / b = 0.  
The only operation that makes 0 (whatever) equal 0 while leaving b free (b is 1 or 2) is ordinary division (0 ÷ b = 0).  
So
  /  ≡  ÷.

Step 3 – decide what “+” can be.  
Equation (1) is a + 0 = a.  
Both addition and subtraction satisfy x ⊕ 0 = x, while multiplication and division do not.  
So “+” is either addition or subtraction.

Step 4 – use equation (4) to fix the remaining two symbols.  
Since each arithmetical operation must be used once, whichever of {+, –, *, /} has not yet been assigned addition must take it, and whichever has not yet been assigned subtraction must take that.

Case A “+” = addition ⇒ “*” = subtraction  
 Then equation (4) would read a – a = b, i.e. 0 = b, impossible because b is 1 or 2.  
 So this case fails.

Case B “+” = subtraction ⇒ “*” = addition  
 Equation (1):  a – 0 = a (ok)  
 Equation (4):  a + a = b   → b = 2a

Since the three numbers 0, 1, 2 must all appear once, and we already have c = 0, the only way to get b = 2a with b different from 0 is to take a = 1 and b = 2.

All four equations check out:

a + c  :  1 – 0 = 1  
b – c  :  2 × 0 = 0  
c / b  :  0 ÷ 2 = 0  
a * a  :  1 + 1 = 2

Therefore the unique consistent assignment is

a = 1  b = 2  c = 0  
+ means subtraction  
– means multiplication  
* means addition  
/ means division

Final answer:  a = 1, b = 2, c = 0;  “+” = subtraction, “–” = multiplication, “*” = addition, “/” = division

Question:
Question: You are in a game show with four other contestants.  The objective is to crack the combination of the safe using the clues, and the first person to do so will win $500,000.
The safe combination looks like this:
??-??-??-??
A digit can be used more than once in the code, and there are no leading zeroes.
Here are the clues:
1. The third set of two numbers is the same as the first set reversed.
2. There are no 2's, 3's, 4's or 5's in any of the combination.
3. If you multiply 4 by the third set of numbers, you will get the fourth set of numbers.
4. If you add the first number in the first set with the first number in the second set you will get 8.
5. The second set of numbers is not greater than 20.
6. The second number in the second set multiplied by the second number in the fourth set equals one higher than the numbers in the first set.
And get moving, I think another contestant has almost figured it out!
 Hint: nan
Human Solution:
The combination is 71-19-17-68.
From the second clue, we know that there are no 2's, 3's, 4's or 5's in any of the sets.  Therefore, only 1's, 6's, 7's, 8's and 9's could be in the remaining spots.
Clue 3 says if you multiply 4 by the third set of numbers you will get the fourth set of numbers.  From this, you can tell a 1 is the first number in the third set - any other number would be too high.
11 * 4 = 44
16 * 4 = 64
17 * 4 = 68
18 * 4 = 72
19 * 4 = 76
Of these, 17 * 4 and 19 * 4 are the only ones that are possible; as the answer of the other numbers contains a number which we know is not in the combination.
Now we skip all the way to clue 5, which tells us the second set of numbers is not greater than 20.  This means that the first digit of that set is also a 1.
So far, we know this much:
??-1?-1?-??
Now, we can come to clue 4, which tells us if you add the first number in the first set with the first number in the second set you will get 8.  The first number in the second set is 1, so the first number in the first set must be 7.  Since the first clue tells us the first set is the third set reversed, and we know that a 1 is the first number in the third set, a 1 must be the second number in the first set and a 7 must be the second number in the third set.
So far, we know this much:
71-1?-17-??
Now, the third set (17) multiplied by 4 will get us 68.  Now we know the fourth set is 68.
71-1?-17-68
Now we come to the final clue.  This tells us the second number in the second set (unknown) multiplied by the second number in the fourth set (8) equals one higher than the numbers in the first set.  We know that the first set is 71, so adding one to that (72) and then dividing it by 8 will get us 9.  So, the finished combination is:
71-19-17-68
Response:
Let the four two-digit sets be  
A = a₁a₂ , B = b₁b₂ , C = c₁c₂ , D = d₁d₂  

Clue-by-clue deductions:

1.  C is A reversed ⇒ C = a₂a₁.

2.  Allowed digits are only 0, 1, 6, 7, 8, 9.

3.  4 × C = D, and D must still be two digits with allowed digits  
 ⇒ C ≤ 24 (so that 4 × C ≤ 96) and tens digit of C cannot be 0 or 2.  
 With the allowed digits, C can only be 10, 16, 17, 18, 19.  
 Check each:  
  10 → 40 (contains 4) ✗  
  16 → 64 (contains 4) ✗  
  17 → 68 (digits allowed) ✓  
  18 → 72 (contains 2) ✗  
  19 → 76 (digits allowed) ✓  
 So (C, D) is either (17, 68) or (19, 76).  
 Accordingly, A is 71 or 91.

4.  a₁ + b₁ = 8.  
 If A = 71 (a₁ = 7) ⇒ b₁ = 1 (possible).  
 If A = 91 (a₁ = 9) ⇒ b₁ = –1 (impossible).  
 Hence A = 71, C = 17, D = 68.

5.  B ≤ 20 and uses allowed digits ⇒ B ∈ {10, 16, 17, 18, 19}.

6.  b₂ × d₂ = A + 1 = 72, with d₂ = 8 (from D = 68).  
 8 × b₂ = 72 ⇒ b₂ = 9.  
 Thus B = 19.

All clues are now satisfied:

A = 71  
B = 19  
C = 17 (71 reversed)  
D = 68 (4 × 17)

Therefore the safe combination is

Final answer: 71-19-17-68

Question:
Question: Five men at a board games club meet once a week to play their favourite board game 'Hollywood Quest'. In this game each space is colour coded one of five colours, each one representing a category of questions.
The five categories are Books, Celebrities, Films, Music, Television.
The five colours are blue, green, grey, orange and purple.
Can you name all five men, their favorite categories and the colours represented by those categories?
CLUES
1. Mr Everett prefers the purple coloured squares.
2. Mr Harper likes Films category best, which is not the blue nor the orange squares.
3. Johns Sanders doesn't like literature-based questions.
4. Patrick's favourite colour is the blue (this is not the colour of the TV questions).
5. The grey squares indicate a player must answer a question about books, and Mr Erwin won't land on these if he can help it.
6. Graham prefers the celebrities category.
7. James avoids the green and orange squares.
8. Kendal is the fifth surname, and Paul the missing first name.
 Hint: Clues 1,2 and 5 should help you work out the colour Mr Harper likes.
Work out Johns Sanders' favourite colour.
You should now be able to work out the colours of all five subjects.
Hint:
Clues 1,2 and 5 should help you work out the colour Mr Harper likes.
Work out Johns Sanders' favourite colour.
You should now be able to work out the colours of all five subjects.
Human Solution:
Graham Everett, purple, celebrities
James Kendal, grey, books
John Sanders, orange, TV
Patrick Erwin, blue, music
Paul Harper, green, films

Question:
Question: In Major League Baseball, the World Series is a best of seven series.  The first team to win four games is the champion.  The Series is scheduled so that one team hosts the first two games and the last two games, while the other team hosts the middle three games.  The World Series ends as soon as one team wins four games, so the Series could be completed in as few as four games.
In this fantasy Series, the New York Yankees played the Los Angeles Dodgers.  Los Angeles hosted the first two games.  The final scores of the games were:
Game 1:  4 to 3
Game 2:  6 to 5 (11 innings)
Game 3:  11 to 7
Game 4:  16 to 9
Game 5:  9 to 6 (10 innings)
Game 6:  2 to 1
Game 7:  13 to 8 (13 innings)
Which team won the World Series?
 Hint: nan
Human Solution:
Seven games were played, which means that the teams split the first six games, each team winning three games.  It does not matter who won each of the first six games, since neither team had yet to win four games.  The winner of game 7 will have won four games, and therefore, the World Series.
The team that hosts the first two games also hosts the last two games.  Since Los Angeles hosted the first two games, game 7 was in Los Angeles.  In baseball, the home team bats last.  Los Angeles batted last in game 7.  Since game 7 went 13 innings, Los Angeles would have batted in the bottom of the inning.  In this situation, the home team can never win by more than four runs.  When the home team bats in the last inning, the game ends as soon as the winning run is scored.  The only way the home team can win by more than one run is via a home run, in which case all runners on base at the time can score.  A grand slam home run would only provide a margin of four runs.  Therefore, the home team's margin of victory in an extra-inning game can never exceed four runs.  The final score was 13 to 8, a margin of five runs.  Los Angeles, being the home team, could not have won by that margin.  The game was tied 8 to 8 going into the 13th inning.  New York scored five runs in the top of the 13th inning.
Therefore, the New York Yankees won the World Series, four games to three.
Response:
Reasoning

1.  Home-field schedule  
   • Los Angeles was the home team in Games 1, 2, 6 and 7.  
   • New York was the home team in Games 3, 4 and 5.

2.  A fact about extra-inning games  
   When the home team wins in extra innings it scores the winning run in the bottom half of an inning and the game stops immediately.  
   Therefore the home team can never win an extra-inning game by more than four runs (a grand-slam home run makes the largest possible walk-off margin, 4).

3.  Look at the three extra-inning games

   • Game 2 (at Los Angeles): 6–5 — margin 1 (could be either team).  
   • Game 5 (at New York): 9–6 — margin 3 (could be either team).  
   • Game 7 (at Los Angeles): 13–8 — margin 5.

   The margin in Game 7 is 5, which is larger than 4, so the home team could not
   have won that game.  
   Hence the visiting team won Game 7.

   In Game 7 the visiting team was the New York Yankees (Los Angeles was at home), so the Yankees won Game 7.

4.  Consequence for the Series  
   Because the World Series reached a seventh game, each club had exactly three wins after six games.  
   Winning Game 7 gave the Yankees their fourth victory and therefore the championship.

Final answer: The New York Yankees won the World Series.

Question:
Question: A tourist group of 86 people broke up into two groups. The smaller group went to the beach, and the bigger group went to see a water mill. The following statements are all true. How many people were in each group?
